articles.title: New start date for the Anthropocene proposed – when humans first changed global methane levels
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Anthropocene is the name given to the period of Earth history when humans have had a global effect on the planet's climate and ecosystems. Despite formal rejection as a geological epoch, it's widely accepted that humans have been reshaping the environment for at least 10,000 years.

articles.author: AOL

articles.title: Climate change could double summer rainfall in the Alps: study
articles.author: Potter Leader-Enterprise
articles.summary: Short, intense summer rainfall in Alpine regions is likely to become more frequent and severe in the future because of global warming, according to a study released Thursday by the University of Lausanne (UNIL). In a scenario where temperatures rise by 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 degrees Celsius), an intense storm currently expected once every 50 years could occur once every 25 years.

articles.title: World has 3 years left to stay below 1.5 degrees warming: study
articles.author: Korea Times

articles.title: Arctic warming spurs growth of carbon-soaking peatlands
articles.author: The Peninsula
articles.summary: Peatlands are expanding as the climate warms. Peatlands are the largest terrestrial store of carbon, locking away twice as much CO2 from the atmosphere as the atmosphere. The change could slow global heating in the near term, but have opposite effect in the future.

articles.title: UK risks more extreme, prolonged heatwaves in future
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The UK could see more frequent extreme and prolonged heat due to climate change, according to the Met Office. The island nation is bracing itself for its first heatwave of the year. The chance of exceeding 40 degrees Celsius has been rapidly increasing and it is now over 20 times more likely than it was in the 1960s.

articles.title: Arctic warming spurs growth of carbon-soaking peatlands
articles.author: Olivier MORIN
articles.summary: Arctic peatlands are expanding as the climate warms. This could slow global heating in the near term but have opposite effect in the future. Peatlands store twice as much CO2 as all the world's forests and are the largest terrestrial store of carbon.
